choices.text: The origins of the Standard Gauge used in modern-day railway systems can be traced back to a time when horse-drawn carriages were the primary mode of transportation. As steam locomotives began to replace horses, it became necessary to establish a uniform track width that could accommodate both horse-drawn and steam-powered vehicles. In 1846, a group of British railway companies agreed upon a gauge of 1,435 millimeters (4 feet, 8.5 inches) for their tracks, which became known as the Standard Gauge. This decision was based
